content:
The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Injunctive relief may include costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, including costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, including costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. Section 621(a)(2)(A) is amended to include "negligent, willful, or knowing violations" for enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission. Increased requirements for consumer reporting agencies and information furnishers are mandated under Section 3. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in relevant sections. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in relevant sections, ensuring that all relevant information is reviewed and considered. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require the Bureau to provide reports on consumer disputes to relevant parties at appropriate intervals. Rules will be prescribed for gathering information on disputes received by consumer reporting agencies for generating these reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to establish rules for gathering information on disputes received by consumer reporting agencies to ensure accuracy in consumer reports. The Bureau will prescribe the type, format, and frequency of information to be received from each agency. Compliance procedures for accuracy in consumer reports are also outlined. The Bureau will issue a proposed rule to ensure maximum accuracy of consumer reports by consumer reporting agencies, considering factors like matching names, date of birth, and social security numbers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include requirements for accurate consumer reports, such as providing consumer information like names, date of birth, social security numbers, and other relevant details. Furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies are also required to exclude any new or additional information during reinvestigations. Additionally, disclosures to consumers under the Act are modified to ensure accuracy in reporting. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include requirements for accurate consumer reports and disclosures to consumers are modified to ensure accuracy in reporting, including providing credit scores derived from credit scoring. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include requirements for accurate consumer reports and disclosures to consumers are modified to ensure accuracy in reporting, including providing credit scores derived from credit scoring models widely distributed for credit transactions. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include notification requirements for adverse information and redesignating subparagraphs in subsection (g)(1). The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include free disclosure requirements after notice of adverse action or offer of credit on less favorable terms within 14 days. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now requires consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with a free copy of their credit report and other disclosures within 14 days of receiving notice of adverse action or offer of credit on less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates that consumer reporting agencies must provide consumers with a complimentary copy of their credit report and related disclosures promptly after being informed of adverse action or less favorable credit terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to notify consumers of adverse actions or less favorable credit terms and provide them with a free copy of their credit report and related disclosures. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates that consumer reporting agencies inform consumers of negative information and provide them with necessary disclosures. Additionally, the Bureau is required to define specific disclosure requirements within a year of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act's enactment. The Bureau must publish a proposed rule within a year of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act's enactment to implement disclosure requirements. Considerations include providing consumers with information to understand adverse actions and protect consumer privacy. SEC. 4. REGULATORY REFORM.

The Bureau will establish 3 registries of consumer reporting agencies within 180 days of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act's enactment. All consumer reporting agencies must register with one of these registries. SEC. 5. STUDY OF A PUBLIC CREDIT REPORTING SYSTEM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, accuracy of existing consumer credit reporting systems, feasibility of a national government-administered system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
